title: How to Let Kids Help in the Kitchen

methods.name: Involving Children in the Meal Planning

steps.headline: Decide on a meal together.
steps.description: Give children a cookbook or show them a website and let them browse through the recipes and pictures. Have them pick out 2 or 3 meals they like. If you have younger children, you can suggest 2 different meals and ask which they prefer. Children will be more willing to participate in the kitchen if they are interested in what you’re cooking.

steps.headline: Have kids read the recipe out loud.
steps.description: This is a good way to expand their vocabulary and get them familiar with kitchen terminology. There still may be words they haven’t heard or seen before, but they should try their best to pronounce them. Explain any ingredient that is unfamiliar to them. If your children are old enough, have them write out a grocery list of ingredients needed for the recipe.

steps.headline: Take your children to the market with you.
steps.description: Teach them where items are located throughout the grocery store. Have them grab items that are within their reach and drop them into the shopping cart. Allow your children to put groceries away. Most items in refrigerators and pantries are located within your kids' reach. At first, show them where items are located and stored.

steps.headline: Agree on a designated workspace in the kitchen.
steps.description: Children should have an area they can safely reach and that is free of knives, hot burners, and other potentially dangerous items. You can use a counter top in the kitchen and allow them to stand on a stool to safely reach the counter. You can also have them sit at a table nearby.

steps.headline: Let your toddler stir and mix ingredients.
steps.description: Give toddlers little tasks that won’t slow down your meal preparation. You can have them stir a batter, pour ingredients, measure ingredients, and rinse off fruits and vegetables. They can also add prepared ingredients to the meal as you cook. You can increase their responsibilities as they age. Give children praise when they complete a task successfully and thank them for their help. This helps build their confidence and self-esteem.

steps.headline: Work your way up to larger tasks as younger children get more comfortable in the kitchen.
steps.description: You can have younger children use kitchen equipment to help with meal preparation. Kids can whisk eggs, use a can opener, juicer, or garlic press, and boil eggs and pasta. Younger children can also start using plastic or pairing knives to cut ingredients. Kids at this age can begin to help you with meals that are prepared on the stove.

steps.headline: Teach preteen children how to help out with the more complicated parts of the meal.
steps.description: At about 9 years of age children can start reading labels, following recipes, and preparing many parts of dishes themselves. They should have basic knife skills and begin using kitchen appliances. In some cases, they may be able to cook on their own. Preteen children can steam rice, use a food processor and blender, cook soup, and fry hamburgers on the stove top. Children should also be able to put dishes in the oven and remove them.

steps.headline: Allow teenagers to cook most parts of the meal.
steps.description: Teenagers should be able to cook for the family safely with little supervision. They should be trained on how to use all kitchen appliances. Their knife skills should be developed so they can chop, dice and mince ingredients. Teach them how to marinate foods and pan fry steaks, chicken breasts, and other meats. They can also take on more complicated baking recipes.

steps.headline: Keep children engaged by changing their tasks for each meal.
steps.description: During one meal, they can be responsible for unwrapping or tearing apart certain ingredients. Some recipes call for food items that must be broken apart or unwrapped before cooking, such as bananas, lettuce, hard-boiled eggs, oranges, and slices of cheese. For the following meal, assign them the task of measuring, pouring, and mixing. If you have more than one kid helping out, you can have them alternate tasks. Designate a certain task to each child, and then rotate tasks so each child can share the experience equally. For example, allow one kid to put groceries away and the other to retrieve ingredients for lunch, then switch their roles the next time you come home from shopping.

steps.headline: Allow your kids to set and clear the dining room table.
steps.description: Instructing your children to set the table is a way you can allow them to help without necessarily having them in the kitchen. Have your kids count out the appropriate number of forks, spoons, napkins, napkin rings, and placemats for all family members, then have them place each item on the table. Younger children can carry their own bowls and cups to the table. Have your children hand wash the dishes or teach them how to put the dishes in the dishwasher. Let children make place cards for holiday or event seating.

steps.headline: Allow your children to throw food and similar kitchen waste into the trash.
steps.description: You can instruct your kids to throw trash away as soon as it is available to avoid cluttering the kitchen with garbage. Verify that certain trash items are safe to handle before giving them to your kids to throw away. For example, make sure can lids are safely stuffed into the bottom of cans to avoid major cuts and other injuries while handling.

steps.headline: Relinquish some control over to your children.
steps.description: You will notice how much or little interest your kids have in the kitchen. They will make mistakes. They might measure the wrong amount or make a lot of noise while doing their task. Let them complete their tasks their way. It’s part of learning how to be in the kitchen. The more they do it, the more they will learn and want to be in the kitchen.

steps.headline: Have your children ask for permission before starting any work in the kitchen.
steps.description: This may seem obvious at first, but as your kids get more comfortable and independent in the kitchen, they may forget to ask at times. Keep in mind, some things you use in the kitchen may seem simple to operate, but as you use them you might be surprised by how difficult they actually are.

steps.headline: Make it a rule to always wash hands before touching ingredients.
steps.description: Little hands often carry big germs. Have them wash hands with soap and water immediately before beginning any recipe. This is especially important for recipes that involve touching the food directly, like kneading dough, or when mixing ingredients with their hands. Also be sure they wash their hands before and after handling raw meat, poultry, egg, and fish products because these foods can contain bacteria. To show the importance of this rule, you can ask your children what they have been touching and ask them if they want it in their food.

steps.headline: Have your kids wear an apron.
steps.description: Wearing an apron will keep clothes clean. You can have your kids wear an old shirt if they do not have an apron. Have them avoid wearing clothing that is big or loose. Baggy sleeves or clothes could catch fire or get caught in mixer beaters or other equipment.

steps.headline: Teach them how to properly use knives.
steps.description: When using knives, instruct them to point the blade away themselves and keep fingers away from the blade when cutting. First, start with plastic to-go knives at the toddler age. During the preschool and kindergarten years, upgrade to more kid friendly plastic knives. By 8-10 years of age, your kids may be able to use kitchen and chef knives. Make sure they don't put knives or other sharp objects into a sink full of water. Someone could reach in and get hurt.

steps.headline: Keep them from getting burned by using potholders or oven mitts.
steps.description: They should to use potholders and oven mits when handling hot pots, pans, or baking trays. Try getting a colorful potholder that is just for them so they will be excited to use it. Instruct them to turn pot and pan handles in toward the back of the stove. This way no one can bump in to them and knock the pot over by accident. Have them ask for help when using a gas stove. They should never try to relight the pilot light on a gas stove. Only an adult should do this. Remind them to never add water to a pan that has hot oil in it. It could make the oil splatter and burn someone.

steps.headline: Show your children how to properly use all of the kitchen appliances.
steps.description: This includes the oven, stove, blenders, food processors, knives, or other sharp kitchen tools. Remind them they need to give the job their full attention. They should turn off the television and remove other distractions that may disrupt their attention to their task. Make sure they turn off appliances when they are finished using them. Keep electrical appliances away from water to avoid shocks. Have them stay away from electrical sockets, especially if their hands are wet. Teach them to use only microwave-safe cookware in the microwave.
